heading: intel profit shy of estimates
subheading: the world's biggest computer chip company reports second-quarter profits that just miss wall street expectations. but intel says profit and sales will pick up nicely in the second half of the year.
author: reuters
text: intel, the world's largest maker of computer chips, reported second-quarter earnings that were just below analysts' expectations, but said it expected a strong second half of the year. intel reported a second-quarter net income of us$1.7 billion, or 51 cents a share, compared with last year's net income of $1.2 billion, or 33 cents a share. according to first call, the consensus among analysts was for 53 cents a share.second-quarter revenues were $6.7 billion, down 5 percent from the first quarter of 1999, but were up 14 percent from the $5.9 billion recorded in last year's second quarter. the company had forecast in april that its second-quarter revenues would be flat to down slightly from first-quarter revenues."as expected, second-quarter revenue reflected a seasonal slowdown and we look forward to a strong second half," intel president and chief executive officer craig barrett said in a statement.the santa clara, california, company said it expected third-quarter revenues to be up slightly from the second quarter, and that it expects a strong second half.gross margins -- the measure of how much profit the company makes on each dollar of sales -- are also expected to be up slightly from 59 percent in the second quarter.intel said that its gross margin expectation for the full year is now 60 percent, plus or minus a few points, which is higher than previously expected, due to the positive impact of cost cutting and manufacturing efficiencies.copyright
